conclusion: Calculate the force experienced by each segment of the wire due to the magnetic field and find the resultant force.
The wire is bent into a ν shape with equal side lengths and an included angle of 60°.
The total length of the wire is 2l, so each side of the ν shape has a length of l.
The force on a straight segment of wire carrying current I in a magnetic field B is given by F = I · L · B · sin(θ).
L is the length of the wire segment and θ is the angle between the wire and the direction of the magnetic field.
The angle θ between the wire and the magnetic field is 90° for both segments of the ν shape, so sin(90°) = 1.
For each segment of length l, the force is F_1 = F_2 = I · l · B.
The direction of the force on each segment can be determined using the right-hand rule.
For the left segment, the force will be directed perpendicular to the segment towards the right.
For the right segment, the force will be directed perpendicular to the segment towards the left.
Since the forces are equal in magnitude and directed at an angle of 60° to each other, we can use vector addition to find the resultant force.
The angle between the two forces is 60°, so the resultant force F_resultant can be calculated using the formula for the resultant of two vectors.
Substituting the values, F_resultant = √((I · l · B)^2 + (I · l · B)^2 + 2 · (I · l · B) · (I · l · B) · 1/2).
The magnitude of the Ampere force received by the ν-shaped current-carrying wire is F_resultant = √3 · I · l · B.
